column4: a tar compressed is just like a zip file. but it is unix compatible
Ok, thanks, but I use Ubuntu Server so it has to be cli?
i see. maybe something like rsnapashot ? http://www.debian-administration.org/articles/217
Yea, maybe. Wouldn't it work to just zip a lot of files and then use the ordinary cp command together with a cron job?
it will work. but use tarballs not zip. tar can store unix ownership and file modes etc...
Aha, ok, that would be nice, would tarballs work using files in Ubuntu encrypted Home directory also or will it somehow remove the encryption?
well that i really dunno. if you run from a cron job maybe the tar sees the encrypted files (becouse is not you who is running it) but i dunno

I have heard that the files are mapped from encrypted to be seen decrypted after logging in, BUT that the files also are stored as encrypted. Then if I copy the encrypted (not decrypted) files from wherever they are stored then the encryption will stay on even in a tarball?
i guess so. but can not tell never used enciption myself
and i do not know how easy is to restore encrypted file from a tarball
Ok, well, I have to give it a try then bedfore I schedule it.
if the file is not corrupted. ther is no risk. What i fear is that the encrypted home solution may layout encrypted files in non standar way or something
if the filesystem you try to umount is in use you ca not umunt it.
seems like you are trying to umount your home partition. You can only do that from single user mode (recovery mode)
Hm, I get confused, I hade sda1 and sdb1 before, then I iserted a new hard drive and booted. Hoe could sdc1 be in use?
maybe the new disk changed the order of the disks. sdb is now sdc and viceversa
